texts.definition: A phase in a gameplay instance where eliminate goals, typically directed at other players, are predominant.
markups: <style="Definition">A phase in a gameplay instance where eliminate goals, typically directed at other players, are predominant.</style>
Some games have distinct phases in their gameplay. <style="CurrentLink">Extermination</style> is the one where the focus is upon eliminating, in most cases other players.

The concept of an <style="CurrentLink">Extermination</style> phase way coined to describe the final gameplay phase of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Master%20of%20Orion">Master of Orion</link></style>. The <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Civilization%20(video%20game)%20series">Civilization series</link></style> provides a weaker example since eliminating other players is only one of several end strategy one can have to win those games.

The main challenges of designing <style="CurrentLink">Extermination</style> phases is to make sure that the gameplay has several distinct gameplay phases in which different actions and goals dominate. Not too surprising, <style="CurrentLink">Extermination</style> requires the strong presence of <style="Link"><link="eliminate">Eliminate</link></style> goals, typically made possible by <style="Link"><link="combat">Combat</link></style> or players' experiencing <style="Link"><link="game-over">Game Over</link></style> events. Delaying the most powerful <style="Link"><link="units">Units</link></style> related to <style="Link"><link="combat">Combat</link></style> until the appropriate time is a typically strategy for controlling when <style="CurrentLink">Extermination</style> is to begin.

<style="CurrentLink">Extermination</style> is, often voluntary, the last phase in several games, especially X4 games such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Master%20of%20Orion">Master of Orion</link></style>. The name for this category of games comes from the typical phases of <style="Link"><link="game-world-exploration">(Game World) Exploration</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="expansion">Expansion</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="exploitation">Exploitation</link></style>, and <style="CurrentLink">Extermination</style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Extermination</style> intensified or provokes <style="Link"><link="pvp">PvP</link></style> gameplay and can increase the likelihood of <style="Link"><link="player-elimination">Player Elimination</link></style> if it is possible at all. For this reason, it is often used as <style="Link"><link="endgame">Endgame</link></style> phases, and quite likely creates <style="Link"><link="higher-level-closures-gameplay-progresses">Higher-Level Closures as Gameplay Progresses</link></style> - especially if <style="Link"><link="player-elimination">Player Elimination</link></style> is possible.

By placing <style="CurrentLink">Extermination</style> as an <style="Link"><link="endgame">Endgame</link></style> phase, it works against <style="Link"><link="early-elimination">Early Elimination</link></style> of players. By being a phase during game instances, <style="CurrentLink">Extermination</style> is difficult to combine with <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Quick%20Games">Quick Games</link></style> as these seldom are long enough to contain phases.
